text: <@U025FFUK8RX> has joined the channel

What are peoples views on these 2 ends of the spectrum?
1) A strategy that has a return of 1% and a trigger rate of 100 trades in say 1week
2) A strategy that has a return of 0.1% and a trigger rate of 1000 trades in 1week 
??

elements.text:

1) A strategy that has a return of 1% and a trigger rate of 100 trades in say 1week
2) A strategy that has a return of 0.1% and a trigger rate of 1000 trades in 1week

text: So infrequent big edge vs frequent small edge

elements.text: So infrequent big edge vs frequent small edge

text: Why one rather than the other; why not both?

text: 1.01^100 = 2.7048 and 1.001^1000 = 2.7169, so the latter wins by a tiny amount in a week.

elements.text: 1.01^100 = 2.7048 and 1.001^1000 = 2.7169, so the latter wins by a tiny amount in a week.

text: Also 1000 opportunities to increase that ROI

elements.text: Also 1000 opportunities to increase that ROI

text: Over a month, the former gives you a 53x return, the second a 54x return. So either of those will do well if you can achieve it. You may want to look at other metrics - Liam’s suggestion very good, but also look at variance, biggest draw-down, etc., etc.

text: Your edge is too small, your data set is too small, your process is all wrong and your graph looks like shit. I don't mean to be mean I'm just giving it to you straight.

text: If you're going to pursue strategies with a very small edge you need thousands and thousands of markets. Even 1% is a small edge.

text:
The edge size was my worry, hence questions yesterday.... 
To come up with these i actually took PeterLe's suggestion thinking about simpler situations and how crowd might be reacting, so seemed good it came up with something albeit small... but in reality im not sure im going to find much more..

elements.text:
The edge size was my worry, hence questions yesterday.... 
To come up with these i actually took PeterLe's suggestion thinking about simpler situations and how crowd might be reacting, so seemed good it came up with something albeit small... but in reality im not sure im going to find much more..

text: 0.1% ? Yeah maybe you can work with that if you are experienced but you've got so little room for error that you really can't afford any mistakes or fudges. Any strategy you design WILL have less edge in real life than in testing because all testing tends toward over-fitting, you should build the assumption of an over-fit into your process. The more experienced you are the less allowance you need, with no disrespect I'd suggest you make a big allowance.

The more experienced you are the less allowance you need, with no disrespect I'd suggest you make a big allowance.

text: Forget about back testing and work on your signals until they work better. You're going to need much more edge.

elements.text: Forget about back testing and work on your signals until they work better. You're going to need much more edge.
